Sentencas: Electron beam-induced charging and -stimulated desorption have been used to probe the electronic properties of gadolini-adoped ceria (GDC) surfaces.
Titulo: Charging effects on electron-stimulated desorption of cations from gadolinia-doped ceria surfaces

Sentencas: The main cationic desorption products resulting from electron bombardment are H+, H3O+ and O+.
Titulo: Charging effects on electron-stimulated desorption of cations from gadolinia-doped ceria surfaces

Sentencas: The dependence of the H+ and H3O+ ion kinetic energies and yields on the surface potentials have been systematically investigated.
Titulo: Charging effects on electron-stimulated desorption of cations from gadolinia-doped ceria surfaces

Sentencas: Positive potentials increase the cation kinetic energies linearly while negative potentials reduce the cation yields dramatically.
Titulo: Charging effects on electron-stimulated desorption of cations from gadolinia-doped ceria surfaces

Sentencas: The charging of GDC by electron beam bombardment is dependent on the incident electron energy: negative at lower energy and positive at higher energy.
Titulo: Charging effects on electron-stimulated desorption of cations from gadolinia-doped ceria surfaces

Sentencas: Irradiation with 400 eV electrons can produce a positive surface potential of several volts while irradiation of the sample with 75 eV electrons can produce a negative sample potential of at least -6
Titulo: Charging effects on electron-stimulated desorption of cations from gadolinia-doped ceria surfaces

Sentencas: V. The positive charge caused by high-energy electron irradiation can be neutralized by the negative charge generated by low-energy electrons and vice versa.
Titulo: Charging effects on electron-stimulated desorption of cations from gadolinia-doped ceria surfaces

Sentencas: The probable hole traps are sites close to Gd3+, and the abundant presence of defects at oxygen vacancy-rich grain boundaries can serve as very effective electron traps.
Titulo: Charging effects on electron-stimulated desorption of cations from gadolinia-doped ceria surfaces
